Michigan reported the data for the calendar year, which we aligned with the upcoming school year (i.e., 2023 data was assigned to 2023-24). The 2018-19 data was obtained from Gardner et al., 2020,  which used the same methodology for aggregation to county level.
Does not include private schools and home school children.

Vaccination Type Provided: 4+ DTaP, 3+ Polio, 2 MMR, 3 HepB, 2 Var, 2 HepA
Notes: We provided an approximation of 2-dose MMR rates for each county by taking the midpoint of the ranges provided in Figure 1 of the cited report, by Stanislawski et al., 2019. The provided ranges were 83.9-86.9% (85.145%), 87-90.9% (88.95%), 91-92.9% (91.95%), 93-94.9% (93.95%), and greater or equal to 95%. Given the lack of 2-dose MMR New Mexico data, we believe that this approximation is an adequate proxy for vaccination rates pre-pandemic. However, because this data is not exact and no 2-dose MMR data was provided  post-pandemic, New Mexico was not included in a excluded from the analysis.

Optional survey for Oklahoma schools. Both public and private schools submitted data; however, the participation rate varies. This data accounts for the following percent of Kindergarten students in the following years. 2019-20: 88% of Kindergarteners in public schools, 53% of private schools; 2020-21: 91% of Kindergarteners in public schools, 61% of private schools; 2021-22: 86% of Kindergarteners in public schools, 46% in private schools; 2022-23: 91% of Kindergarteners in public schools, 65% in private schools; 2023-24: 95% of Kindergarteners in public schools, 62% in private schools.

North Central Public Health District MMR rates was distributed to both Wasco and Sherman counties as this two-county health department services both counties. Any counties where enrollment is less than 10 students are censored. Note: data is provided as year data. We assigned the given year data to the previous school year, inferring this from the data provided on the website (i.e. 2023 data was assigned to the 2022-23 school year.
Every school in the state self-reports comprehensive immunization data (public, private, and home schooled).

Data Source or Link: South Carolina Department of Public Health: https://scdhec.gov/health/vaccinations/childcare-school-vaccine-requirements/school-vaccination-coverage-exemption-data-county-2016-2020

Notes: Complete MMR percent is reported at a county level (both public and private schools) for 2020-21 onwards. For 2019-20 data, the county-level public and private school data was seperated. Therefore, we combined public and private school data by weighting public and private county-level data by enrollment data and then aggregating up to county level.

State Immunization Requirements: Utah Department of Health & Human Services: https://immunize.utah.gov/utah-immunization-rule/
Notes: Utah provided a mix of county-level and school-district level 2-dose MMR rates. For counties where school-district rates were provided, we averaged the school-district rates into a single county-level rate.

Vermont represents any county with a vaccination rate greater than 95% as >95%. Therefore, we cap all vaccination rates at 0.95 for Vermont. The data is reported to the Vermont Department of Health by all public or independent schools.

Vaccination Type Provided: Prior to SY 2021: 4 DTaP, 4 Polio, 2 MMR, 3 HepB, 2 VAR                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        SY 2021 onwards: 4 DTaP, 4 Polio, 2 MMR, 2 HepA, 3 HepB, 2 VAR
Notes: Virginia added HepA to their vaccination requirements in SY 2021, switching from a 4-4-2-3-2 series (4 DTaP, 4 Polio, 2 MMR, 3 HepB, 2 VAR) to a 4-4-2-2-3-2 series at school entry (4DTaP, 4 Polio, 2 MMR, 2 HepA, 3 HepB, and 2 VAR). We included the data due to its completeness; however, we acknowledge that this could contribute to decreases in rates post SY-2021.
Schools with less than 10 individuals are not included due to privacy concerns.

State Immunization Requirements: West Virginia Office of Epidemiology & Prevention Services: https://oeps.wv.gov/immunizations/Pages/default.aspx

Notes: Wisconsin reported the data for the calendar year, which we aligned with the upcoming school year (i.e., 2023 data was assigned to 2023-24).

Wyoming reported the data for the calendar year, which we aligned with the upcoming school year (i.e., 2022 data was assigned to 2022-23). WY Data was excluded from the analysis because the target age group varies over time, resulting in highly variable data. However, the data is still available in the Github file. We note the following discrepancies when analyzing the data. 2018-19 data collects 2 MMR data from 6-year-olds, state average MMR rate is 71%. School years 2019-20, 2020-21, and 2021-22 collect data for 7-year-olds, where the state averages are 72%, 76%, and 76%, respectively. 2022-23 data reports 2 MMR for Kindergarteners, where the state average is 91%. Immunization rates are obtained from the Wyoming Immunization Registry (WyIR), except for the 2022-23 Kindergarten rates, which are obtained from the 2022 Immunization Status Report. Note, the WyIR tends to underestimate true adoloscent coverage because  actual vaccines administered is often under-reported, as documented here: https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/WDH-IMM_Immunization-Data-Technical-Notes-Rev..pdf
